posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked: Anyone else have trouble with their limelight not seeing the April tags due to glare off the clear Lexan from the spot lights. I am with Team 2338 and at CIR our Limelight would not recognize the April tags on the stage. We believe it was due to the reflection off the Lexan covering the April tags. It worked on all the other April tags just not on the stage. Any suggestion?

posts.name: Corey Applegate
posts.cooked:
We most definitely observed this while checking cameras during field calibrations but since we don’t rely on the stage we are ignoring them.

I should mention we are in Iowa.

posts.name: kylelanman
posts.cooked:
I was the CSA down on the field talking to your team.  The tag in question when looking at it from a very steep angle up had a spot light hitting it that completely washed out the top corner of it.

Year after year I find myself wanting regionals to ditch production stage lighting and to just use the normal venue lighting.  It seems foolish to provide targets that theoretically should work well for teams and then to make them useless with stage lighting.

posts.name: Smtopps
posts.cooked: Many teams had issues with this on the red speaker at Newmarket Ontario. It was never perfect but us and others I talked to found increasing resolution at the expense of frame rate helped.

posts.name: Michael Hill
posts.cooked: Might be time to start looking at polarizing filters

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: If the spot lights can’t be moved, then the best you can do with LL is play with the Exposure, Black Level Offset, and Sensor Gain. Pipeline Setup | Limelight Documentation You can also try polarized sunglasses. I’ve had to put mine in front of a camera lens on occasion. Getting the angle right might be tricky. Circular polarization might work. https://www.amazon.com/VIOFO-Filter-Anti-Glare-Circular-Polarizing/dp/B09MY9YHNV/ref=asc_df_B09MY9YHNV/

posts.name: Luke
posts.cooked: We had some issues when staging our robot on one side of the subwoofer because of a certain overhead light that caused too much glare for our limelight to detect the tags. We’re planning on adding a second limelight on the back of our robot to add some redundancy; otherwise I think it’s best just to avoid the areas with glare and try to find them during practice matches/field calibration time. I don’t really want to give up the stage lighting just because it’s cool and makes events exciting, but it might be better for reliability in some cases.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
kylelanman:

Year after year I find myself wanting regionals to ditch production stage lighting and to just use the normal venue lighting.

Says you. Some venues have rather inadequate venue lighting at certain times of the day, to the point of wanting extra lights!

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked: Polarizing filters for the lenses can help with glare issues, but require custom mounting solutions.

posts.name: coderkevin
posts.cooked: We noticed the higher we pointed our cameras, the more glare issues we would have in our shop. If possible, I’d recommend trying to tilt your camera down a bit more. I know that can make it difficult to see the stage tags, but the chain will probably get in the way anyway.

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked: Polarizing filter was our thoughts also. One of our mentors mentioned it right away. But I think we were to focused on the overall event. But in hind site it was a big time killer for us to have to line up manually and caused issue. Working on this now but having trouble recreating the issue in our shop. Probably have to make a couple of solution to test at an event with the issue.

posts.name: Max
posts.cooked:
coderkevin:

We noticed the higher we pointed our cameras, the more glare issues we would have in our shop.

To put more context to this, our shop has a low (a few feet above our replica speaker), tiled drop ceiling, with lights every other tile. (The usual school/office ceiling)

We were having glare issues because the camera was catching the ceiling lights reflection off of the april tag due to its angle lining it up with a ceiling light, which is why angling the camera down more could help, as it could catch less glare from closer lights, as its less inline with lights and the tag.

This might help on an actual field because the lights are farther up, making it harder to catch a reflection from them at a low angle, but easier at a higher angle. At least thats my thought process on this.

posts.name: Dan Langdon
posts.cooked: We had issues with beam breaks in our shooter that were being tripped by the lights in addition to some difficulty viewing some April tags. And with just one period of field calibration it made it very difficult to fix when it was discovered in matches

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked:

I created and printer this adapter for a 30mm camera CPL lens filter. Just use some double sticky tape and the filter can be mounted and removed as needed. Let ya know how it works out.

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked: Out of curiosity, what cameras are those?

posts.name: Neil
posts.cooked: That’s a Lime Light 3. The filter is just a generic 30mm lens filter. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0C82DRVMC?ref=ppx_yo2ov_dt_b_product_details&th=1

posts.name: Marcus Kauffman
posts.cooked: I meant the cameras in the post I was replying to.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked: They’re OV2311 cameras in a basic 3D printed housing. You can read about our vision system in our build blog

posts.name: Adithya Anand
posts.cooked: Hey, do you have the STL file for this? We redesigned our vision system to now use all the tags, and we want to make sure that the stage tags are visible and are planning on using a polarizing filter.
